Author: dimxy#2587
Content: @jl777c  what about the output variable names in heirinfo? Now they are called like 'owner inactivity time, sec', 'spending allowed for the heir',... (with spaces). Probably not very good names for rpc. Maybe, better to make them shorter and with no spaces?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
There is a question about the suggestion to heir cc by @dukeleto to add a memo field.
Seems, just to add this memo with the owner's will is not enough because it is not clear for the Heir cc how to fulfill  the conditions in this memo. Now Heir cc contract unconditionally allows to spend the funds for the heir, if inactivity time is passed.
If we want to add some real world will, seems, we need who would execute its conditions. That is, we probably need 3-rd person, an executor of the will. He should add his signed permission to spend funds from our 1of2 cryptocondition where the funds are.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems to create a lot of unsolved issues and require trusted arbiter

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: Evidently yes, as it is going to be a connection to the real world (outside the blockchain)

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: I added this memo field to the new fix and marked it as 'for future use'

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @dimxy i see heir CC + memo field data being used together, to bridge the gap from "blockchain smart contract" to "signed + human notarized PDF of a will" (which stands up in court)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: no legal precedent for heir CC, means it needs help to be considered "real". tying together a legal will with a heir CC, i think makes it much stronger

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the will can specify exactly what the heir CC is, and give instructions to the heir on how to use it, solve all the "icky" real-world problems that heir CC internals avoid

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: to clarify, my idea is that memo fields + heir CC's get tied together at a higher level, up the stack, not changing the heir CC to use memo fields directly

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @radix42 you might have some opinion re: the above ^^^

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
Little issue I found on params validation stage.
Negative txfee retrurns error:
```./komodo-cli -ac_name=TONY11 heirfund -1 100 test 024f4f2b781c247b3609ba777a222d93d44182466c01dad3f2aa0def2be8f69e56 100
error code: -1
error message:
incorrect txfee param```
Random text input as txfee accepts (creating tx with default txfee so it not seems a big issue, but anyway I think it's not good that text input accepting in this field):
```
 ./komodo-cli -ac_name=TONY11 heirfund tony 100 test 
024f4f2b781c247b3609ba777a222d93d44182466c01dad3f2aa0def2be8f69e56 100
{
  "result": "success",
  "hextx": ""
}
```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Mihailo `git merge -Xtheirs` or `git merge -Xours` will either resolve all conflicts with the other branch, or your current branch's changes. Sometimes it's what you want

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: -X lets you tell git a "merge strategy"

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@dimxy I am going through the heir doc now,
```
After the inactivity time has passed, both the heir and owner may freely claim available funds. This is achieved by that that after the first heir spending, a special flag is set depicting that spending is allowed for the heir from now on, whether the owner adds more funds or spends them.
```
Can you explain who sets the special flag ? miners or the heir when he submits the claim transaction?

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: the heir sets this flag when he successfully claims funds first time  (after inactivity time passed)

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: Got it.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
```
When using Heir contract on a private chain, to make funds available for the heir, you should wait for inactivity time and add any arbitrary transaction to the chain (for the duration between owner tx and chain tip to be calculated correctly).
```
"you should wait" --  here is it the heir?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @dimxy are private funds be able to use in inheritance? If not what is the difference here from a purely public chain?

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: well I suggest removing this (this is just for testing), sorry, overlooked

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: So, there are no special/extra things to be done by anyone for the heir contract in a private chain that are not needed in a public chain?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: I mean is there any difference in the usage of the contract on a chain where private transactions are possible VS a pure Public chain?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @dimxy

Author: dimxy#2587
Content:
I used the name 'private' chain incorrectly, I meant 'test chains'
There is no differences in using heir cc on various chains
The difference might be in that on KMD chain heir cc will be used with coins, on asset chain it will be used with tokens. It supports both

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: Ah, got it. Will just delete the note.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
Is this statement true:
```
The `heiradd` rpc call warns the user that he is making a donation to the fund if he is neither the **owner** nor the **heir**
```

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
```
The `heiradd` rpc call doesn't allow addition of funds from both owner and non-owner inputs in a single transaction. In any case such fund additions will be considered as donations too.
```
So the rpc call doesn't allow it, but if someone creates a raw transaction manually to include both owner and non-owner inputs in the fund transaction, will the other nodes reject it? @dimxy I mean does such a txn break consensus rules?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how can someone else spend funds out of owner address?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: If the wallet has utxo of both owner pubkey and and another pubkey then can't a txn be constructed that adds funds from both to the heir fund?

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: Yes, here it states about if someone manages to create a tx with both owner inputs and other inputs (having both keys)

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: Is it an artifical situation?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only the owner would be able to do that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless he is hacked

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but if this tx is rejected anyway, what is the issue?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: I am asking if it is rejected

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: I mean is it rejected now according to the heir contract

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: Such tx would not be rejected now and it would be considered as donations to the heir fund (if it is created bypassing the rpc)

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: we are speaking about normal inputs BTW

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: Got it.  So such a txn won't reset the countdown to inactivity period?

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: yes donations won't reset the inactivity countdown

Author: dimxy#2587
Content: only owner tx will do that

Author: gcharang#6833
